I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of Indonesia for subprogram 3 of the Infrastructure Reform Sector Development 
Program (IRSDP). The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
2.  Prior to the 1997 Asian financial crisis, Indonesia used infrastructure development to 
support poverty reduction and economic development.1 However, the financial shock resulted in 
cancellation or suspension of many public and private infrastructure projects. During 1998–
2004, the government was burdened with the urgent tasks of financial sector restructuring and 
fiscal consolidation. As a result, infrastructure investments, which accounted for more than 6% 
of gross domestic product (GDP) before 1998, fell to a low of 2% in 2000 and fluctuated around 
3% in 2001–2006. While investment in infrastructure has started to increase, expenditures have 
not reached pre-crisis levels. By 2008, infrastructure investment had risen to 3.95% of GDP, but 
was still insufficient to meet the country’s growth aspirations and the growing demand from 
existing infrastructure users, let alone satisfy the large population that is lacking access to basic 
infrastructure  services.  In  2009,  in  response  to  the  global  financial  crisis,  the  government 
included  a  substantial  infrastructure  component  in  the  fiscal  stimulus  package.  Although 
infrastructure spending is now close to 4% of GDP, it is still insufficient to sustain the country's 
aspirations of growth of 6% or higher as well as growing demand from infrastructure users. The 
government projects that an additional annual infrastructure investment of 2% of GDP is needed 
to increase access for the marginalized segments of the population, and satisfy the large 
population lacking access to basic infrastructure services. 
   
3.  The government’s priority assigned to infrastructure, and the role of the private sector in 
providing it, was first emphasized during the 2005 Infrastructure Summit as the first high profile 
public–private dialogue. It sent strong messages to global investors about the willingness of the 
government to support the infrastructure agenda. At the time, the government estimated that 
about $65 billion would be needed in new infrastructure investments, with $25 billion (38%) to 
be sourced from its budget; $14 billion (22%) from domestic banks, insurance, and pension 
funds; $10 billion (15%) from multilateral and bilateral development partners; and $16 billion 
(25%) from domestic and foreign private sector investors.  
 
4.  The government fully recognized that private sector participation could not be taken for 
granted,  and  that  major  structural  and  institutional  reforms  were  needed.  The  IRSDP, 
formulated  jointly  by  the  government  and  its  principal  development  partners,  supports  a 
comprehensive medium-term reform agenda in various infrastructure sectors. The program loan 
supports three key reform components, which are (i) strategic cross-sectoral reforms, (ii) sector-
specific  reforms  for  transportation,  power,  oil  and  gas,  water  supply  and  sanitation,  and 
telecommunications; and (iii) facilitation of the preparation of public–private partnerships (PPPs) 
resulting in sound model infrastructure projects that can be replicated. 
 
5.  The IRSDP comprises a cluster of three subprograms, a project development facility 
(PDF) for the preparation and execution of PPP infrastructure projects, and technical assistance

B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
6.  The IRSDP, of which subprogram 3 is an integral part, will improve Indonesia’s overall 
investment  climate  by  removing  infrastructure  bottlenecks  and  increasing  access  to 
infrastructure services, and thereby support timely realization of the government’s medium-term 
macroeconomic goals, in particular average GDP growth of 6%–7% per annum during 2010–
2014. The expected outcome of the IRSDP will be accelerated infrastructure development 
through major private sector participation and mobilization of additional public sector resources. 
The impact of the IRSDP has been positive. GDP growth accelerated from 5.0% in 2004 to 
6.8% in 2009 following the 2008 global economic crisis, and infrastructure investments rose 
from 2.9% of GDP in 2005 to about 4% in 2008 with these levels being maintained if not higher 
for 2009 and 2010. In 2006, the government planned to increase capital spending on national 
public infrastructure by at least 25% by 2010 but managed an increase of 90%. Similarly 
investments for increasing piped water connections rose to $296 million in 2009 from $30 million 
in 2007, the electrification ratio rose to 65% at the beginning of 2009 from 62% in 2004, and 
percentage of national roads in good and/or fair condition increased to 86% in 2010 from 81% in 
2006. These outcomes demonstrate the effectiveness of the reforms under the IRSDP program 
and the experience suggests the usefulness of dialogue in advancing new ideas with key policy 
makers, as well as the importance of regular dialogue to maintain the momentum on the reforms 
being undertaken.  
 
7.  The  PDF  facility  with  a  total  funding  of  $34.1  million  will  help  maintain  the  pace  of 
infrastructure  reforms  because  it  is  project  based.  Further  ongoing  support  will  also  be 
channeled through infrastructure finance and the operations of the Indonesia Infrastructure 
Finance Facility (IIFF).  
 
8.  The IRSDP was designed as a cluster of three single-tranche subprograms, supporting 
three core areas: (i) cross-sectoral reforms, (ii) sector-specific reforms, and (iii) facilitation of 
PPPs. The design has proved to be resilient, and appropriate. Subprogram 3 initially comprised 
70 policy actions with 75 outputs. Without affecting the overall thrust of the IRSDP, 6 outputs 
were dropped taking into account changing circumstances without affecting the overall reform 
agenda.5 Delays were incurred on 5 of the 6 outputs because ministerial regulations took longer 
than expected for the sector operational guidelines manual and implementation of the waste

1.  Cross-sectoral reforms 
 
10.  The IRSDP has played an important role in creating the enabling environment for PPPs 
by supporting the development of a cross-sectoral policy and legal framework defining PPPs. 
Most recently, the President signed Decree 13/2010 to update Decree 67/2005, clarify issues in 
areas such as providing support to national and subnational projects, and require government 
purchase of project land prior to issuing PPP concessions. MOF has prepared draft regulations 
that  will  revise  the  PPP  government  support  framework  and  formally  operationalize  the 
Indonesia  Infrastructure  Guarantee  Fund  (IIGF),  which  was  launched  in  May  2010  and  is 
designed to be a credible guarantee provider for PPP projects. 
 
11.  Operating guidelines have been prepared for the preparation of PPP projects, and the 
government is presently preparing supporting documents to guide project preparation at the 
sector level. Institutional reforms have led to the separation of policy and regulatory functions in 
sectors such as transport, energy, and water. Regulations now permit line agencies such as the 
Ministry of Transport and the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources to establish PPP nodes 
to develop projects.

4 
 
12.  The government has made progress in establishing financing mechanisms to support 
public  and  private  sector  portions  of  PPP  projects.  The  public  service  obligation  (PSO) 
framework has been successfully implemented in the energy sector, and payments are being 
made to the State Electricity Corporation (PLN) every 3 months. The PSO framework provides 
PLN with the necessary liquidity to continue operations. The IIFF6 was established through the 
joint efforts of MOF, ADB, DEG (Deutsche Investitions- und Entwicklungsgesellschaft mbH) and 
the World Bank, and is now in the process of obtaining a license so that it can commence 
operations. IIFF is expected to be an important source of PPP project preparation advice and 
long-term local currency finance. 
 
13.  The government has taken steps to resolve land acquisition issues and submitted a draft 
land acquisition law to Parliament to replace a law dating back to 1961 and requiring the 
government to acquire land in the public interest for infrastructure projects. The new law will 
embrace the following five basic principles: (i) land appropriation for public purposes should not 
be  hampered;  (ii)  landowners  will  not  suffer  losses  if  their  land  is  taken;  (iii)  real  estate 
speculation will not be allowed; (iv) land appropriation procedures should conform to best 
international practices; and (iv) land appropriation should take into account current land disputes 
in Indonesia and, to minimize conflict, be respectful of the history of the people. The new law, 
expected to be enacted in 2011, will remove one of the most important constraints on PPP 
project preparation. MOF has announced that it will establish a land fund that will operationalize 
the requirement for the government to procure land under Perpres 13/2010. 
 
2.  Sector-specific reforms 
 
14.  Transportation  sector  reforms.  Laws  on  railways  (23/2007),  shipping  (17/2008), 
aviation (1/2009), and road traffic and transportation (22/2009) were enacted to separate policy 
and regulatory functions from operations. Tariff regulations based on cost recovery principles 
have been put in place. Most implementing regulations identified in the policy matrix have been 
implemented or are in the process of being implemented. The outstanding regulations that have 
not yet been approved primarily relate to issues such as technical and safety standards, which 
will not act as constraints to private sector participation. Various port and rail projects have 
already  been  approved  for  development,  and  a  number  of  these  projects  (e.g.,  Central 
Kalimantan Railway and Soekarno Hatta–Manggarai Railway Link in Jakarta) are expected to 
be structured as PPPs. Once the new land law is in place, road projects, such as the Trans-
Java road projects, will start to move forward.  
 
15.  Energy  sector  reforms.  New  laws  on  energy  (30/2007)  and  electricity  (30/2009) 
provide  the  basis  for  permitting  private  sector  participation  in  the  power  subsector  on  a 
competitive basis. Implementation of these laws has been delayed and five of six implementing 
regulations are still pending.7 However, this does not appear to be acting as a constraint on 
private  sector  investment  in  power  generation;  several  power  purchase  agreements  were 
signed in 2010, and the concession for the Central Java Power Project is expected to be 
competitively tendered as a PPP in 2010. A great deal of private sector interest is apparent in 
geothermal power projects, and several concessions are expected to be financed as PPPs.

16.  Water sector reforms. Funding requirements of the PDAM debt rescheduling program 
have hindered progress in the water sector; however, the government has made significant 
steps by launching the restructuring program in 2009. Although a new law on local government 
enterprises that would provide greater autonomy to the PDAMs has yet to be enacted, many 
PDAMs  have  started  preparing  the  business  plans  necessary  for  encouraging  greater 
investment  in  their  operations.  Some  examples  include  several  large  bulk  water  PPP 
concessions being developed by the Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID)-
funded Indonesia Infrastructure Initiative Program in Java.  
 
17.  The potential for pursuing PPPs in the solid waste sector is high. Several projects have 
been implemented in Jakarta and Bali on a competitive bidding basis instead of a business-to-
business approach indicating that progress is being made. The government enacted the law on 
environment (32/2009), which provides the framework for environment standards. The separate 
waste  management  law  (18/2008)  requires  all  stakeholders  to  uphold  waste  management 
policies across the country.  
 
18.  Telecommunications  sector  reforms.  The  telecommunications  sector  is  fully 
competitive with 11 public and private companies offering one of the lowest tariffs in Asia. Fixed-
line density is about 3.7% and cellular phone density 6.9%. The Ministry of Communication and 
Information issued Decree 02/2010 on the Strategic Plan for 2010–2014. In particular, under the 
government-promoted  universal  service  obligation  scheme,  telephone  services  are  being 
extended to 10,000 remote villages, bringing the number of villages connected to around 32,000 
(out of approximately 70,000).  
 
3.  Facilitation of public-private partnerships 
 
19.  Status of PPP transactions. In March 2010, two independent power producers (PT 
Paiton Energy for a 815-megawatt expansion of the East Java Power Plant and Cirebon Electric 
Power for the 660-megawatt Cirebon Power, West Java) were initiated with financing from the 
Japan Finance Corporation. Moreover the specific PPP output under subprogram 3 (financial 
closure for two PPP projects, prepared and tendered in full compliance with Perpres 13/2010) is 
progressing although their financial closure is expected in 2011. Tendering has been initiated for 
three PPP projects: (i) Solo–Kertosono Toll Road, (ii) Central Java Power Plant, and (iii) Central 
Kalimantan Coal Railway. BAPPENAS has offered another six projects including (i) Bandung 
Waste-to-Energy Project; (ii) Soekarno Hatta–Manggarai Railway Link; (iii) Tukad Unda Water 
Supply,  Bali;  (iv) Tanah  Ampo  Cruise  Ship  Terminal,  Bali;  (v)  Maros  Water  Supply,  South 
Sulawesi; and (vi) Umbulan East Java Water Supply. While some of these projects may face 
issues in terms of investment size (e.g., Tanah Ampo Cruise Ship Terminal and Maros Water 
Supply) or viability (Soekarno Hatta–Manggarai Railway Link), achieving financial closure is 
likely for at least three projects totaling $3 billion during 2011–2012. These are the Central Java 
Power Plant, Central Kalimantan Coal Railway, and Umbulan East Java Water Supply. Aside 
from the current BAPPENAS list of projects, a pipeline of other projects are being prepared 
given  the  improved  enabling  framework  for  PPP  and  increased  investor  interest  in  the 
Indonesian market. In short, PPP transactions are anticipated to accelerate, particularly with the 
establishment of IIFF and the IIGF. 
 
D.  Program Costs and Financing  
 
20.  Based on its financing requirement and planned borrowing from other sources, the 
government has requested a loan of $200 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to help

6 
finance the program. Subprogram 3 is a continuation of subprograms 1 and 2, and the intensity 
and significance of the policy content in terms of actions and outputs is comparable to the 
previous  subprograms  and  completes  the  three  subprogram  cluster.  The  loan  size  was 
determined by the strength of the policy package, its development impact, the importance of the 
sectors covered, and the adjustment costs including land capping ($100 million), revitalization of 
PDAMs ($400 million), support for the Government Investment Unit ($100 million. The IRSDP 
program also called for successfully undertaking some key reforms which were politically very 
sensitive such as mandating open and competitive bidding under revised Perpres 13/2010 and 
facilitating  passage  of  the  Electricity  Law  which  had  been  previously  annulled  by  the 
Constitutional Court in 2004. Furthermore, the proposed subprogram loan will also help to close 
the  financing  gap  for  2010  to  maintain  a  budget  deficit  of  less  than  2.1%.  
The loan will have a 15-year term, including a grace period of 3 years, an annual interest rate 
determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending 
facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per year, and such other terms and conditions set forth 
in the draft loan agreement. The government has provided ADB with (i) the reasons for its 
decision  to  borrow  under  ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending  facility  based  on  these  terms  and 
conditions, and (ii) an undertaking that these choices were its own independent decision and not 
made in reliance on any communication or advice from ADB. 
 
21.  In parallel, the World Bank is also considering a similar loan of $200 million for the fourth 
subprogram of its Infrastructure Development Policy Loan,8 which is scheduled for consideration 
by the World Bank’s Board on 18 November 2010. 
 
22.  The loan proceeds will be used to finance the full foreign exchange costs (excluding 
local taxes and duties) of items produced and procured in ADB member countries, excluding 
ineligible items, and imports financed by bilateral and multilateral sources. In accordance with 
the provisions of ADB’s Simplification of Disbursement Procedures and Related Requirements 
for Program Loans, the reimbursement procedure will be used to disburse the loan proceeds 
based on certification by the borrower.9 Subprogram 3 will provide retroactive financing for 
eligible expenditures incurred up to 180 days prior to loan and grant effectiveness. ADB will 
retain the right to audit the use of the loan proceeds and to verify the accuracy of withdrawal 
application certification.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Economic and Financial 
 
26.  The IRSDP reforms are expected to have short- and long-term net benefits. These 
include a reduced fiscal burden from the gradual removal of the fuel subsidy and improved cost 
recovery in all infrastructure sectors. A road map for fuel subsidy was prepared and is being 
discussed  internally.  The  PSO  policy  framework  provides  the  basis  for  better  targeting  of 
infrastructure service provision, connectivity, and access for low-income groups. The PDAM 
debt-restructuring  program,  which  commenced  in  2009,  will  reverse  the  decline  in  service 
quality and coverage of water supply and sanitation. PLN’s restructuring in December 2009 and 
a tariff hike of 10% for higher income consumers in July 2010 will help lower the government 
subsidy while improving PLN’s efficiency. Passage of the Electricity Law (30/2009) will provide 
the foundation for medium- to long-term improvements in electricity supply and efficiency as the 
conditions  for  private  sector  investment  begin  to  improve  and  subsequent  investment  in 
generation  increases,  in  turn  improving  the  overall  investment  climate.  The  introduction  of 
independent  transport  and  utility  regulators  in  the  longer  term  will  remove  government 
interference  in  utility  operations  and  pricing,  providing  the  basis  for  improved  efficiencies. 
Economic benefits are expected to accrue from improved quality of existing roads through better 
road maintenance and vehicle load control, and expanded road networks; improved access to 
markets and other forms of connectivity; and lower vehicle operating costs. Major general 
economic benefits will accrue to the entire Indonesian population through the expanded scope 
and improved quality of infrastructure services.

8 
 
B.  Governance 
 
27.  The IRSDP is strengthening the key institutions dealing with infrastructure development 
in Indonesia. At the national level, KKPPI, its secretariat, and MOF’s risk management unit are 
evolving  into  institutions  that  coordinate  central  support  for  private  sector  participation  in 
infrastructure development. The PPP unit located at the BAPPENAS central office is providing 
support  for  the  development  of  infrastructure  projects  covering  all  sectors.  Within  each 
infrastructure  sector,  the  regulatory  bodies  will  be  strengthened  over  the  medium  term  by 
enhancing their autonomy, clarifying their mandate, and providing adequate resources for their 
operations.  The  newly  established  IIFF  provides  long-term  financing  for  private-sector-led 
infrastructure  projects and  is  timely  given  the  financing  difficulties for  private  infrastructure 
investment as a result of the global financial crisis. The recently launched IIGF provides public 
sector contingent liability support for PPP projects.  
 
28.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and BAPPENAS. Consistent with its commitment to good governance, 
accountability,  and  transparency,  the  government  has  considerably  strengthened  its 
anticorruption efforts under the incumbent President since he first rose to power on an anti-
corruption  platform  in  2004.  Similarly  the  Financial  Action  Task  Force  also  pointed  out 
deficiencies in Indonesia’s efforts in combating money laundering and the financing of terrorism. 
The government has been reforming procurement for some time, resulting in a competitive and 
relatively transparent selection of bidders by the public sector. The private sector participation 
regulatory framework, adopted as part of the IRSDP, sets out clear guidelines for the selection 
of private sector sponsors. KKPPI is tasked with ensuring that the tendering processes are fair 
and transparent. Furthermore, the President of Indonesia has considerably enhanced the profile 
and visibility of the Anti-Corruption Commission and other law enforcement agencies to deal 
effectively with corruption. These steps are already having a positive impact. 
 
C.  Poverty and Social 
 
29.  The  IRSDP’s  main  contribution  is  to  improve  the  investment  climate  and  thereby 
contribute directly to poverty reduction through greater access to markets, and economic and 
employment opportunities. The policy reforms are intended to lead to increased infrastructure 
investments by the public and private sectors. On balance, the poverty and social impacts of the 
reforms and ensuing investments will be positive, through the benefits of induced economic 
growth and the improved provision of infrastructure services. The increase in domestic oil prices 
by almost 30% in May 2008 also freed up much-needed additional funds for more pro-poor 
spending. The government is constantly reviewing tariff policies in all sectors and attempting to 
adopt tariff regimes that are in line with cost-recovery principles. At the same time, the impact of 
tariff increases on the poor is mitigated through appropriate measures such as conditional cash 
transfer  programs.  Potential  negative  impacts  include  social  dislocation  and  inadequate 
compensation for land acquisition. The government established the Land Working Group to deal 
with  issues  of  land  zoning  and  purchase  of  land  in  anticipation  of  future  infrastructure 
developments; the results will be incorporated in the new land law expected in 2011. Overall, 
the IRSDP is leading to significant social benefits. 
 
D.  Safeguards 
 
30.  The IRSDP has been classified under environment category C since its onset as the 
IRSDP measures are unlikely to have any adverse environmental impacts. The involuntary

9 
resettlement and indigenous people impacts categories are also C. As for future investments in 
infrastructure by either the public or private sector or by PPP modality, existing presidential 
regulations 36/2005 and 65/2006 recognize traditional communal land ownership and usufruct 
rights. In line with the regulatory provisions, the rights of indigenous peoples are upheld in case 
of any land acquisition involving them. These provisions are in conformity with requirements 
outlined in ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). Most of the reforms supported by the 
IRSDP help improve environmental outcomes through better sanitation, higher electricity prices 
to promote energy conservation, promotion of recycling, and sanitary landfills. Furthermore, 
while the IRSDP facilitates the preparation and tendering of several PPP projects, it does not 
provide any investment support to such projects and the government ensures that all social and 
environmental safeguards are complied with in line with the prevailing laws and regulations. 
 
E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
31.  Government commitment. The government confirms that it remains strongly committed 
to  the  reform  program  embodied  in  the  IRSDP  and  the  complementing  Infrastructure 
Development Policy Loan program. The 2014 elections pose only a moderate risk of weakened 
commitment and a loss of the reform momentum, as even with a change of government, the 
next leaders are expected to continue focusing on economic growth and poverty reduction to 
ensure a sound tenure in office and mitigate the risk of social and political unrest.  
 
32.  Government capacity and coordination. While the government remains committed to 
reform objectives, the ability to translate that commitment into practical reform achievements is 
subject to available capacity within the different government ministries and agencies. In several 
areas, progress has been slower than anticipated by the government when the IRSDP was 
agreed upon. This has typically been the result of low capacity. Mitigation strategies include 
realistic outputs and schedules based on likely reform progress, and continued provision of TA 
for  capacity  building.  The  ongoing  TA,  attached  to  the  first  subprogram  (footnote  3),  is 
addressing capacity constraints at BAPPENAS and MOF. In some instances, the progress of 
infrastructure reforms has been impeded by poor coordination among government ministries 
and agencies, and competing and conflicting interests of various stakeholders. While full and 
effective coordination and reforms in certain sectors may take time to evolve and need further 
consensus building, the  essential  steps  taken  thus  far will  have  a  demonstration  effect  in 
supporting infrastructure development in a coordinated manner in the coming years.  
 
33.  Governance. With the high stakes involved in large infrastructure projects in several 
sectors, the IRSDP may face significant impediments in the form of weak governance, collusion 
and corruption, or lack of judicial capacity to enforce good governance measures. In particular, 
despite the commendable rigid stance taken by MOF, risks of misallocation of scarce public 
resources could still be encountered during the transition period, leading to government support 
for directly negotiated projects or projects that do not meet all relevant criteria for such support. 
However, the government has considerably strengthened its anticorruption efforts through the 
establishment of the Anti-Corruption Commission and other law enforcement agencies, as well 
as tightening national procurement guidelines. 
 
34.  Macroeconomic stability. Domestic macroeconomic volatility, adverse global events 
such as high oil and food prices, or natural disasters could impede private sector participation. 
Indonesia has considerable gross financing needs and the cost of meeting these will almost 
certainly go up if outlays on oil subsidies and budgetary financing needs continue to increase. In 
such an environment, a sharp deterioration in global economic conditions could make Indonesia 
particularly vulnerable to sudden shifts in investor sentiment, possibly triggering rapid capital

10 
outflows and increasing the risks of broader financial sector disruption. However, since 2006, 
the Indonesian economy has been quite resilient to domestic and external shocks and the 
government’s macroeconomic policies have been sound. 
 
35.  Social issues. Tariff reforms are sensitive in any environment, and Indonesia is no 
exception. As the country is gradually moving away from administered prices and tariffs for 
infrastructure products and services, social tensions are inevitable. However, the government 
has so far been successful in reducing such tensions by use of the two-pronged approach of 
(i) comprehensively socializing any planned price and tariff increases, and (ii) using the savings 
from the reduction in inefficient subsidies for direct poverty reduction, employment generation, 
and rural infrastructure development. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES 
 
36.  The  government  and  BAPPENAS  have  assured  ADB  that  implementation  of  the 
program shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption 
measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as 
described  in  detail  in  the  loan  documents.  In  addition  to  the  standard  assurances,  the 
government has given the following additional assurances, which are also incorporated in the 
legal documents:  
(i)  Counterpart funds generated from the proceeds of the subprogram 3 loan will be 
used to finance the development needs as outlined under the subprogram 3 
implementation arrangements. 
(ii)  The  policies  and  actions  taken  prior  to  the  date  of  the  subprogram  3  loan 
agreement, as described in the letter of development policy (including the policy 
matrix), will continue to be in effect after the completion of the IRSDP. 
(iii)  The studies and technical designs prepared for PPP projects will broadly comply 
with all relevant ADB requirements, policies, and guidelines. 
(iv)  Recommendations resulting from the work done under the technical assistance 
(footnote 2) will be implemented to the fullest extent possible, and within a timely 
manner. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
37.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  acting  in  the  absence  of  the  President,  under  the 
provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, I recommend that the Board 
approve  the  loan  of  $200,000,000  to  the  Republic  of  Indonesia  for  subprogram  3  of  the 
Infrastructure Reform Sector Development Program, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, 
with interest to be determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-
based lending facility; for a term of 15 years, including a grace period of 3 years; and such other 
terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan 
agreement presented to the Board.

Dear Mr. Zoellick, Mr. Kuroda, and Ms. Ogata 
The purpose of this letter is to confirm the Government of Indonesia's intent to proceed with the Fourth 
Infrastructure Development Policy Loan (IDPL4) extended by the World Bank, and the third sub-
program of Infrastructure Reform Sector Development Program (IRSDP 3) extended by the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  the  Government  of  Japan  through  the  Japanese  International 
Cooperation Agency (JICA). 
The close collaboration of the ADB, the Government of Japan and the World Bank in support of the 
Government's infrastructure reform program has contributed to advancing the reform agenda in the 
sector. ADB, JICA and the World Bank have targeted different areas of the Government's infrastructure 
reform program. Key policy actions have been included in the World Bank IDPL4, that should be read 
in conjunction with the appropriate IDPL policy matrix, while a complementary set of policy actions 
have been included in the ADB IRSDP3 policy matrix, for which JICA is providing joint support. 
IDPL4  and  IRSDP3  are  the  last  in  the  programmatic  series  of  loans  targeting  infrastructure 
development. As such, we would like to offer some concluding remarks on the general effectiveness of 
the IDPL1-4 and IRSDPI-3 series.

28  Appendix 4 
 
The World Bank's Infrastructure Development Policy Loan 
 
National Infrastructure. A major hurdle for improved infrastructure in Indonesia has been the 
significant dip in infrastructure spending following the 1998 financial crisis. Over the course of the 
four-year IDPL dialogue, infrastructure spending has grown steadily. Beyond the higher levels of 
public finance, the Government has sought to implement a multi-sector reform program that enables 
greater access to infrastructure services. Of special note are the policy efforts to maintain public 
allocation for infrastructure at both the national (APBN) and sub-national (APBD) levels, which as of 
today are higher than those levels anticipated under the IDPL series. At the national level the 
allocations have been more than three times the targets. In addition, reforms in the power and water 
sectors are beginning to show promising results. 
In the power sector, a tariff adjustment that has been stipulated through Ministerial Regulation No. 
712010 which regulates the average tariff increase up to 10% is expected to achieve the above targets. 
It is highlighted that by this regulation, a better pricing policy also signals a better investment climate 
in electricity sector. As a result, we are considering a tariff adjustment mechanism that would place the 
sector on a stronger financial footing thereby encouraging more investments in the electricity sector. 
For Roads financing, medium-term planning has begun and medium-term budgeting has been initiated 
by the Ministry of Public Works (MoPW) in close consultation with the Ministry of Finance (MoF) 
and the World Bank. For the Road Preservation Fund, presidential decrees are being drafted that will 
establish management, organization and governance guidelines for the Fund. 
Sub-National  Infrastructure.  In the water sector, an increasing number of PDAMs are being 
financially restructured, supported by a robust intercept mechanism which will allow the restarting of 
public support for those utilities. Moreover, public support will be implemented through an output-
based Hibah grants mechanism that was recently initiated to increase connections as well as a 
guarantee/subsidy scheme for commercial bank lending to PDAMs. 
Public-Private  Partnerships.  There  has  been  some  progress  in  the  area  of  Public  Private 
Partnerships (PPP). The financial architecture is almost complete as the Indonesia Infrastructure 
Financing Facility JIFF) and the Indonesia Guarantee Fund (IGF) are both expected to become 
operational this year. Despite progress in the institutional set-up, the system remains challenged when 
it comes to supporting credible PPP transactions. 
Environment and Governance. Beyond hard infrastructure spending, the IDPL series has been 
helpful in supporting and strengthening the governance of the MoPW in its basic operations and 
policies. These include the introduction of electronically-based procurement systems as well as

Appendix 4     29   
 
 
the introduction of Risk-Based Internal Audit programs throughout MoPW. The MoPW has initiated 
audit programs for its activities in up to 12 provincial offices. In the area of land acquisition, several 
ministries and agencies are drafting a major piece of legislation governing land acquisition that will 
make the process `faster' and `fairer' for all, particularly the poor. 
ADB and JICA's Infrastructure Reform Sector Development Program Loan 
The IRSDP has supported the Government's strategy of accelerating infrastructure development 
through large-scale private sector participation. To provide a conducive environment for private 
investments, a comprehensive policy, regulatory and institutional framework, which is in line with 
international best practices, has been established. The new framework has still to pass the test of 
successful implementation of public-private partnership projects in order to signal Indonesia's readiness 
for private investment. The Government and development partners should therefore focus their efforts 
on the preparation and execution of public private partnership (PPP) projects in the pipeline that could 
be replicated in the future. 
The IRSDP has highlighted the importance of having reform champions at the highest levels of the 
Government to provide guidance on the direction and pace of reforms, as well as of building up 
ownership at the middle government levels and in state-owned enterprises to ensure effective reform 
implementation. Given the natural inertia of these constituencies and the fact that some infrastructure 
reforms run counter to their interests, this task needs time and perseverance. 
Good governance in both public and private provision of infrastructure is central to ensuring mutual 
accountability.  The  Government  has  implemented  reforms  in  public  procurement  to  enhance 
transparency and thereby reduce the scope for corruption. The new framework for private sector 
participation in infrastructure development has introduced transparency and competition into the 
selection of private sector sponsors, instead of the previous approach of direct negotiations. 
The key bottleneck has been land acquisition and the prospects for addressing the land acquisition 
challenge are increasingly positive. First, Perpres 1312010 requires that the central or local government 
has to acquire land before a PPP project is tendered. Second, the Government is in the process of 
developing a new Land Acquisition Law that is anticipated to be passed in early 2011. The proposed 
Law will build on the previous reform measures to introduce compensation based on market rather 
than taxable value, freezing land prices at a specific point in time for negotiation purposes, and setting 
up a predictable and time-bound system for negotiating and resolving the final payment to the 
landowners. It will be important to continue to track developments related to streamlining land 
acquisition.

30  Appendix 4  
 
 
 
Concluding Remarks 
We understand that infrastructure investment and maintenance is still too low in order to sustain current and 
obtain  targeted  economic  growth  rates.  The  creation  of  adequate  new  employment  opportunities  and 
expanding access to basic infrastructure services will require vast improvements in basic transport, energy, 
water provision and other infrastructure areas. However, we are pleased with the positive policy developments 
provided by the World Bank, ADB and JICA support over the past four years, and believe that it has provided 
a sound platform for further growth and future cooperation.
